bullets.text: U.S. Supreme Court struck down Trump’s “reciprocal” tariffs, reshaping trade policy constraints but leaving near-term pricing and supply-chain uncertainty for firms and consumers.
Trump announced a new 10% global tariff after the ruling, signaling renewed escalation risk for imports, inflation, and retaliation despite court limits on prior authority.
U.S. 2025 Q4 GDP grew 1.4% (miss) while inflation firmed near 3%, complicating the Fed outlook with weaker growth but sticky prices.
Consumers shouldn’t expect immediate price declines from tariff rollback; contracts, inventories, and uncertainty keep pass-through slow and uneven across categories.
Fed Z.1 “Financial Accounts” for 2025:Q4 releases March 19, 2026—key for tracking leverage, credit growth, and sector balance-sheet stress.
Private credit stress signals: Blue Owl liquidity curbs and illiquid loan exposure raise fears of redemption pressure and pricing gaps in opaque private markets.
OpenAI told investors compute spend could approach $600B by 2030, implying unprecedented AI capex, power demand, and chip supply-chain competition.
AI isn’t yet eliminating all white-collar work; adoption remains task-specific, with productivity gains and job reshaping outpacing broad displacement so far.
U.S. military positioning in Jordan and Trump’s strike comments heighten Iran confrontation risk; oil markets face upside supply-shock tail risk.
Hungary is an obstacle to Europe’s proposed €90B loan to Ukraine, highlighting EU unanimity constraints and potential delays to Ukraine financing.
Student-loan delinquency reportedly nears 25%, a growing household-balance-sheet risk that could pressure consumer spending and credit performance.
Parkinson’s trial implants dopamine-producing stem cells, suggesting a potential disease-modifying therapy path beyond symptom management.
Oxford battery advance could enable faster charging and longer-lived lithium-ion cells, improving EV economics and grid storage competitiveness if it scales.
